reviews.title: An amateur offering
reviews.text:
An amateur offering. With Family Building Society, you cannot access statements from your online account. Instead, you receive a monthly email containing a link to your statement. However, I discovered that if you open a more recent statement (for example December), the link to an earlier one (such as November) expires and becomes inaccessible.

The only way to rectify this is to call them, wait for an answer, then go through seven security questions before requesting that the statement be sent again. These included full name, account number, first line of address, postcode, date of birth, National Insurance number, and occupation.

I have never known a financial organisation to require seven security questions, nor to provide such a poor online and telephone setup. This feels unprofessional and not what I would expect from a modern financial institution.

Their call-back service is particularly valuable, especially when it’s not convenient to wait on the phone. reviews.title: The new "improved" online service
reviews.text: What a disaster.  As an existing customer I had no problems with the old online service but following the introduction of the new service I had to reapply to access my online account.  This was a lengthy procedure followed by waiting for a Verification Code to be received by post.  Having then gained online access to the account I was asked to check my profile details and so needed to change my mobile telephone number.  After several failed attempts, i.e. no response after clicking the "confirm" button, I again had to telephone FBS.  After a lengthy call, and even then only after  consultation with another colleague to get round the problem, was the agent able to input the new number from his end.  This is a joint account so it seems that my wife also needs to go through this whole time consuming and frustrating process if she is to access the account.  It will be far far easier for me to close the account and transfer the money to another provider.  Do the writers of these online websites ever check that their programs work before they are forced on the customer?  In view of this experience I can no longer recommend The Family Building Society for online savings.

reviews.title: Very helpful staff member, Cameron, on telephone.
reviews.text: I set up my new account with Family Building Society today, but very soon I was locked out because it would not accept my User ID and/or password.  And then I had to deal with changing my password -  which involved passcodes that didn’t arrive and other delays.  So I rang Family BS and was fortunate to be able to explain my problems to  Cameron Bell, who was tremendously patient in talking me  through everything, with the result that I can now get into my account quickly and without any difficulty.  So, a happy outcome!

reviews.title: Hurrah for The Family Building Society.
reviews.text: The Family Building Society had updated their internet banking system and seldom using it I had to re-register but got confused with passwords, etc., so called their IT help line. Nicole calmed me down, saw me through each possible error situation and got me going again. Her patience was admirable, especially after us waiting 5 mins for an email to arrive only for me to notice my broadband had disconnected. In my 70s I easily get irate when faced with computer probs but  I was guided in a non-judgemental way with care and consideration. Three days later she called back to check I was happy. If only all companies were so efficient: I can see why they are called the Family Building Society.
